Key Arguments: The legislation goes beyond addressing issues like vandalism of 5G towers or live-streaming atrocities and extends into areas of political debate.
The bill exempts government communications from being considered misinformation or disinformation, which is seen as Orwellian.
The legislation could suppress speech on social media that contradicts government claims.
Historical examples, such as the misinformation about Iraq's weapons of mass destruction, illustrate the dangers of such powers.
Free speech is crucial and should not be limited, as it is more dangerous to society to restrict speech than to deal with false claims.
Notable Quotes: The fact that the bill explicitly exempts any government communication, of any level of government, from being considered misinformation or disinformation, shows how Orwellian this law will be.
Social media is rife with misinformation and disinformation; but the only way to combat it is to publicly refute it, not censorship.
Regulating truth on social media will not protect democracy, it will suppress it.
